headline: Now, Even The Rich Shop At Dollar Tree
summary: Shares of Dollar Tree gapped sharply lower Wednesday even though the company beat quarterly sales and profit expectations and raised its full-year outlook.  The discount retailer — which completed the sale of Family Dollar in July — reported adjusted earnings from continuing operations of 77 cents a share, up 13%.  Dollar Tree's same-store sales rose 5.9%, a combination of 2.8% higher shopper traffic and a 3.1% higher average ticket.

headline: Tariff pressures hit Dollar Tree hard
summary: The retailer saw its shares tumble 7.9% to $102.56, reflecting investor concerns about tariffs, inventory issues, and margin pressures.

headline: Heard on the Street Wednesday Recap: A Chrome-Plated Rally
summary: Tech shares rallied. The Nasdaq Composite rebounded 1% on Wednesday, and the S&P 500 added 0.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed a slim 24 points. A reprieve for Google sparked the jump. A court ruled that Google could keep its Chrome browser and still make payments to partners such as Apple to distribute its products.

headline: DLTR Q2 Deep Dive: Expanded Product Assortment and Cost Pressures Shape Outlook
summary: Discount treasure-hunt retailer Dollar Tree (NASDAQ:DLTR) reported Q2 CY2025 results topping the market’s revenue expectations, with sales up 12.3% year on year to $4.57 billion. The company’s full-year revenue guidance of $19.4 billion at the midpoint came in 1.3% above analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.77 per share was 87.6% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Should Investors Buy the Post-Earnings Dip in Dollar Tree Stock?
summary: Despite crushing Q2 earnings expectations, Dollar Tree (DLTR) stock dipped 8% on Wednesday but is still up more than +35% year to date.
